{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3401956,"name":"Jack brannon","username":"Jbrannon","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e47c2d/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-25T20:12:51.195Z","cooked":"

My team is considering running some off season workshops for middle and high schoolers in our area to be introduced to FIRST and robotics in general. Does anyone have any ideas of electrical themed activities that could be included as a part of the electrical learning workshops other than powerpoints and test board demonstrations?

Try SOLDERING!

Small Arduino projects are fun, can be short and you see an immediate connection between code controlling circuits.

Reaction tester games, led control, controlling a relay, potentiometer to servo control, etc.

There are tons of examples for all of these Arduino projects, I just remember them specifically as I taught them to kids as young as 4th grade with success before. Any younger and the wiring and typing can be a bit much.

projecthub.arduino.cc

A Simple Reflex Game

A fun game to test your reaction time!

Arduino Getting Started

Arduino - Servo Motor controlled by Potentiometer | Arduino Tutorial

Learn: how Servo Motor works, how to connect Servo Motor to Arduino, how to program Arduino step by step. The detail instruction, code, wiring diagram, video tutorial, line-by-line code explanation are provided to help you quickly get started with...

https://docs.arduino.cc/built-in-examples/control-structures/ForLoopIteration/

If OP likes the soldering idea my team got kits with 6 different soldering projects to build devices that did something - sound, lights. Cost was about $35 for each package of 6 projects and we got several packages - one per student. Most students liked the activity. Sorry I can’t remember the electronic hobby kit company we got them from but I see dozens of projects on the Internet from $5 to $35 each.
Something like this:
https://www.jameco.com/z/WSG102-Velleman-Velleman-MadLab-1-2-3-Game-Kit-Solder-Assembly-by-Whadda_2354999.html

then this:
https://www.jameco.com/z/WSL104-Velleman-Velleman-Sound-Activated-LEDs-Kit-by-Whadda_147571.html
will keep interested students busy for awhile.

At a local maker Faire a group was doing a very small soldering activity with a custom pcb. You would solder the battery and a led using through holes. The pcb had a design for the maker Faire and had a spot for a pin to be added so they can wear it. It will be a short activity but fun and fairly cheap

I’ve used the “learn to solder” badges many times, but not for FRC. Something to keep in mind; the battery holder and pin are fairly funky to solder vs leads. For FRC, I would start the kiddos out on some one pad per hole perf board so they can get used to how that behaves, then let them do the badge.

ALSO: watch what solder you buy! You need -actual- flux in the stupid solder! I can’t believe people actually sell non-flux solder You want rosin mildly activated.

Old school eutectic Lead solder is way easier than the modern Lead free stuff. Yes, its a a bit hotter and you have to wash your hands afterwards, but that smooth action and “if its shiny its a good joint” thing rocks. So worth it!

Weldingrod1:

Lead solder

Just ignore the skull and crossbones warning on the package /j

The roll we have has one on it and the students always wonder why we keep it. As long as you have eye protection (should be on anyways when using any tools), nitrile gloves, use a smoke absorber and don’t eat it you’ll be fine.

Also if you have lots of extra “junk” wire they can practice the “NASA-splice”

western-union-or-linemans-splice514×580 55.3 KB

For @Jbrannon I found the soldering kits my team bought. I see the price has increased dramatically recently. There are several other kits lists on this web site near this one: 4-in-1 Learn to Solder

List of Kits

Weldingrod1:

Old school eutectic Lead solder is way easier than the modern Lead free stuff. Yes, its a a bit hotter and you have to wash your hands afterwards, but that smooth action and “if its shiny its a good joint” thing rocks. So worth it!

Leaded eutectic solder has a lower melting point than no-lead eutectic solder. (That’s one of the reasons it’s harder to learn no-lead, IMO, because the flux is more prone to burning off before the metal melts.)

Leaded solder is easier to learn and I think more forgiving overall. But it mixes really poorly with no-lead solder and a lot of what we do in electronics is repair/rework of existing items [most of the new items are no-lead/RoHS], and it’s even harder to have a mix of leaded and no-lead/RoHS items on the same tools/bench.

With that in mind, at home I’ve almost entirely switched over to no-lead for new work and have one small soldering station that I keep for leaded work.

Another tip: give your students access to an external flux pen and/or syringe. Nothing teaches them more quickly about the purpose/utility of a clean joint than struggling with a joint for a while and then seeing how much easier it is with added fresh flux.

Good points there!

Oddly enough, at SLB we actually have some soldering stations specifically for -leaded- solder because we need the higher melting point; its referred to as HMP solder. Downhole tools get HOT Cross contamination can lead to components falling off downhole!

I’ll have to see about a flux pen; sounds like a great demo!
